summary: This document is an email chain from November 2008 regarding a request for a written staff opinion from The Florida Bar's ethics counsel. It involves an Assistant U.S. Attorney seeking guidance, likely related to victim notification procedures in a case, and includes attachments of sample victim notification letters and a Florida Bar ethics opinion.

persons.name: Gail E. Ferguson
persons.context: She is the Assistant Ethics Counsel at The Florida Bar who is responding to an ethics inquiry and providing a formal opinion letter.

persons.name: Elizabeth Clark Tarbert
persons.context: She is the addressee of the ethics opinion letter and appears to be an Assistant U.S. Attorney in West Palm Beach who made the initial inquiry.

connections.description: Ferguson, as Assistant Ethics Counsel, is providing a formal written staff opinion in response to an inquiry from Tarbert, an Assistant U.S. Attorney.

events.title: Ethics Opinion Response Sent
events.description: Gail E. Ferguson sends a letter in response to an ethics inquiry, which will be faxed and mailed to Elizabeth Clark Tarbert.

events.title: Follow-up Email Forwarded
events.description: An earlier email requesting a written staff opinion is forwarded to the ethics opinions desk, noting staff assignment to Gail Ferguson.

events.title: Initial Ethics Opinion Request
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney (likely Elizabeth Clark Tarbert) sends a formal request for a written staff opinion to The Florida Bar, attaching relevant documents including sample victim notifications.

keyFacts: The document is an email chain from 2008 involving a request for an ethics opinion from The Florida Bar, initiated by an Assistant U.S. Attorney.
The correspondence includes attachments of sample victim notification letters, suggesting the inquiry is related to proper legal procedures for notifying victims in a case.
Gail E. Ferguson, as Assistant Ethics Counsel, is the designated staff member providing the formal written opinion in response.
The context implies the U.S. Attorney's office in West Palm Beach was seeking guidance on ethical or procedural matters, potentially connected to an ongoing prosecution.
